content.p: Using the description of glucose regulation above, try to answer these questions without looking at the feedback loop diagram. When you are done, click the "next" button to display the completed feedback loop.

response.feedback: Correct. Plasma glucose is regulated by the feedback loop.
Incorrect. The pancreas is an organ, not the variable being regulated.
Incorrect. The liver is an organ, not a regulated variable.
Incorrect. Insulin and glucagon are involved in information flow for the feedback loop, but they are not the variable that is being controlled.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Plasma glucose is the variable being monitored.
Correct. The pancreas contains beta and alpha cells that react to changing blood plasma glucose.
Incorrect. The liver helps regulate plasma glucose, but is not the sensor monitoring levels in blood.
Incorrect. Insulin and glucagon are hormones of the endocrine system that affect glucose homeostasis, but they don't sense glucose levels.

part.hint: Receptors sense the variable being regulated.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Glucose is the variable being monitored.

Correct. The pancreas acts as both the sensor and control center in the regulation of plasma glucose. When it comes to feedback loops involving the endocrine system, the receptor and control center are often the same.
Incorrect. The liver helps regulate plasma glucose levels, but it is not the control center.
Incorrect. Insulin and glucagon are hormones of the endocrine system, but they don't compare glucose levels to the set point.

part.hint: The control center compares the sensed levels (detected by the receptor) of the variable (glucose) against a set point value.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Glucose changes, but in response to physiological responses of the effector caused by insulin and glucagon.
Incorrect. The pancreas is critical to the feedback loop, but it is not an effector.
Correct. The liver cells respond to insulin and glucagon in order to remove glucose from the blood plasma, or release glucose into the blood plasma, respectively.
Incorrect. Insulin and glucagon are hormones that carry information, but are not the effectors themselves.

part.hint: Effectors most directly affect the level of the variable.
